description: From Middle English rasour, from Old French rasour, from raser (“to scrape, to shave”). More at rat.
Displaced native Old English sċierseax (literally “shaving knife”).

entries.meaning: A keen-edged knife of peculiar shape, used in shaving the hair from the face or other parts of the body.
Any tool or instrument designed for shaving.
The sharp tusk of a wild boar.
(philosophy) A conceptual device that allows one to shave away unlikely explanations for a phenomenon.

verbs.description: razor (third-person singular simple present razors, present participle razoring, simple past and past participle razored)

examples: He thought likewise, that what with razoring and tanning, and the change of his clothes, he was not likely to be recognised.
